def remove(col):
    sorted(col)
    q1,q3=col.quantile([0.25,0.75])
    iqr=q3-q1
    low_range=q1-(1.5*iqr)
    upper_range=q3+(1.5*iqr)
    return low_range, upper_range

Mathematical functions

we will see some mathematical functions to detect outliers: ## 1) z-score ![](http://makemeanalyst.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/Z-Score-and-Emperical-rule.png) * This is a normal distribution * 68% of the data points lie between +/- 1 standard deviation. * 95% of the data points lie between +/- 2 standard deviation * 99.7% of the data points lie between +/- 3 standard deviation * Ingredients for calculating z-score: mean, standard deviation. ![image.png](attachment:image.png) * **Rule of thumb : Any z-score greater than 3 or less than -3 is considered to be an outlier.** * Z-score is sensitive to extreme values, because the mean itself is sensitive to extreme values . * This score helps to understand if a data value is greater or smaller than mean and how far away it is from the mean. More specifically, Z score tells how many standard deviations away a data point is from the mean.

Are Outliers really bad?

Outliers are problematic for many statistical analyses because they can cause tests to either miss significant findings or distort real results. Machine learning algorithms are sensitive to the range and distribution of attribute values. Data outliers can spoil and mislead the training process resulting in longer training times, less accurate models and ultimately poorer results.
